text: And Abraham said unto his young men, Abide ye here with the ass; and I and the lad will go yonder and worship, and come again to you.
text_kjv: And Abraham said unto his young men, Abide ye here with the ass; and I and the lad will go yonder and worship, and come again to you.
text_niv: He said to his servants, “Stay here with the donkey while I and the boy go over there. We will worship and then we will come back to you.”
text_esv: Then Abraham said to his young men, “Stay here with the donkey; I and the boy  will go over there and worship and come again to you.”
text_nlt: “Stay here with the donkey,” Abraham told the servants. “The boy and I will travel a little farther. We will worship there, and then we will come right back.”
text_msg: Abraham told his two young servants, "Stay here with the donkey. The boy and I are going over there to worship; then we'll come back to you."
text_nasb: Abraham said to his young men, 'Stay here with the donkey, and I and the lad will go over there; and we will worship and return to you.'
context: The ancient Near East was a world deeply immersed in religious practices, often involving sacrificial rituals. Abraham, a Mesopotamian nomad who migrated to Canaan, was familiar with such practices, although his understanding of the divine would be radically reshaped by his covenant with Yahweh. Sacrifice was commonly used to appease deities, seek favor, or express gratitude. The location, Moriah, while not definitively identified, later became associated with the Temple Mount in Jerusalem, adding layers of significance to this event for the Israelites. The 'young men' accompanying Abraham were likely servants or members of his extended household, reflecting his status as a wealthy patriarch. Donkeys were essential for transportation, particularly across the rugged terrain. Abraham's words and actions in this chapter must be understood against the backdrop of these cultural norms, but also as a stark departure from pagan practices due to his faith in a God who ultimately rejects human sacrifice. Abraham's separation from his servants was intentional; the act of worship was to be a private and deeply personal encounter between him, Isaac, and God. The journey itself was arduous, taking three days, adding to the emotional and spiritual weight of Abraham's impending test. This journey, and the subsequent events at Moriah, would become a foundational story, demonstrating the depth of Abraham's faith and God's provision.
meaning: Abraham's statement, 'we will go yonder and worship, and come again to you,' is a profound expression of faith and obedience. Superficially, it could be interpreted as a deceptive attempt to conceal his true intentions from his servants, but theologically, it reveals a deeper trust in God's power and promise. Abraham had received God's promise that through Isaac, his descendants would be as numerous as the stars. To sacrifice Isaac would seem to nullify this promise entirely. Yet, Abraham, in Hebrews 11:19, is understood to have reasoned that God was able even to raise Isaac from the dead, indicating an extraordinary belief in God's sovereignty and ability to fulfill His word, even in the face of seemingly impossible circumstances. The word 'worship' is also significant. It suggests that Abraham viewed his obedience, even to the point of sacrificing his son, as an act of devotion and reverence to God. It highlights the radical nature of his faith, willing to surrender the most precious thing in his life to the One who had given him everything. 'Come again to you' signals Abraham's unwavering belief that either he and Isaac, or at least he alone, would return. This unwavering hope suggests a deep understanding of God’s character, one who keeps His promises and is ultimately a life-giver, not a life-taker. Thus, this verse is less about deception and more about a profound, unshakeable faith in the God who can do the impossible.
application: In modern life, Abraham's declaration echoes in our own moments of testing and uncertainty. We are often faced with situations where our faith is challenged, where the path ahead seems unclear, and where we are asked to surrender something precious to God. Just as Abraham separated himself from his servants to engage in deep worship and obedience, we must also create space for intimate communion with God, away from the distractions and pressures of daily life. This could involve setting aside time for prayer, meditation, or studying scripture. Abraham's faith in God's ability to 'bring us back' teaches us to trust God's promises, even when circumstances seem to contradict them. We may not be asked to sacrifice a child literally, but we may be called to sacrifice our ambitions, our comfort, our relationships, or our resources for the sake of God's kingdom. This verse encourages us to approach these sacrifices as acts of worship, trusting that God will provide a way forward and fulfill His purposes in our lives. Like Abraham, we must also be willing to go 'yonder,' stepping out in faith, even when we don't know what lies ahead. This requires a willingness to be vulnerable, to surrender control, and to trust that God is working behind the scenes for our good. Finally, Abraham's example reminds us that true worship is not just about outward rituals, but about inward obedience and a heart fully surrendered to God's will. It challenges us to examine our own hearts and to ask ourselves whether we are truly willing to sacrifice whatever God asks of us, trusting that He will ultimately provide.
prayer: Heavenly Father, like Abraham, I often find myself facing difficult choices, where my faith is tested and my path is unclear. Grant me the strength and courage to separate myself from the distractions of the world and to seek your face in prayer and meditation. Help me to trust in your promises, even when circumstances seem to contradict them. I acknowledge that you are sovereign and that your ways are higher than my ways. Grant me the willingness to sacrifice whatever you ask of me, knowing that you will never lead me astray. Help me to see every act of obedience as an act of worship, offered from a heart that is fully surrendered to you. Like Abraham, I choose to believe that you will bring me back, that you will fulfill your purposes in my life, and that you will never leave me nor forsake me. I pray for a deeper understanding of your love and faithfulness, so that I may walk in obedience and faith, even in the face of uncertainty. In Jesus' name, Amen.

faqs.answer: Abraham's statement wasn't necessarily a deception, but a testament to his profound faith. He believed God could resurrect Isaac or provide an alternate outcome, thus fulfilling His promise of descendants through Isaac. This faith allowed him to confidently say they would both return.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse: Why did Abraham tell his servants they would return if he knew he was going to sacrifice Isaac?

faqs.answer: In this context, 'worship' signifies complete submission and obedience to God's will. Abraham viewed his willingness to sacrifice Isaac as an act of devotion and reverence, showcasing the depth of his commitment to God's commands.
faqs.question: Q2: What does it mean that Abraham went to 'worship'?

faqs.answer: Abraham's trust is evident in his belief that either he and Isaac, or he alone, would return. This unwavering hope demonstrates a deep conviction that God is faithful and capable of fulfilling His promises, even when they seem impossible.
faqs.question: Q3: How does this verse show Abraham's trust in God?

faqs.answer: Leaving the servants behind signifies a deliberate separation for a deeply personal and spiritual encounter with God. It emphasizes the intimacy of the act of worship and the unique relationship between Abraham, Isaac, and God.
faqs.question: Q4: What is the significance of leaving the servants behind with the donkey?

faqs.answer: While sacrifice was common, this verse sets the stage for a critical shift. Ultimately, God doesn't desire human sacrifice, but rather obedience and faith. He provides a substitute, foreshadowing the ultimate sacrifice of Jesus Christ.
